items.title: Blink and Gecko on iOS one day?
items.content:
#â€‹579 â€” February 8, 2023 | Read on the web

The Guide to Responsive Design in 2023 and Beyond â€” Ahmad shares a detailed look at modern responsive web design, offering a thoughtful take on how we should think about things in 2023. An excellent and up-to-date primer which may get you thinking about certainÂ approaches.

Ahmad Shadeed

Mozilla, Google Looking Ahead to the End of Apple's WebKit? â€” Following word of Chromeâ€™s Blink-based efforts, work on a Gecko-based version of Firefox for iOS is also said to be underway. Currently only WebKit-powered browsers are allowed on Appleâ€™s iOS â€”Â but the hope from Google and Mozilla is that this willÂ change.

Thomas Claburn

New Courses on the React Learning Path â€” React Performance: Optimize React applications for maximum perfromance. React & TypeScript: Create robust and reliable React apps atÂ Scale.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Ten Web Development Trends in 2023 â€” Following the State of JS survey results Robin takes a considered look at new web dev trends that we should be paying attention to this year, and why theyÂ matter.

Robin Wieruch

Announcing Interop 2023 â€” 'Interop' is an ongoing cross-browser effort to â€œincrease interoperability across browsers in key technical areasâ€. In 2022 significant improvements were made. This post from Mozilla outlines the plan for the year ahead.

James Graham (Mozilla)

ğŸ¤ MORE ON INTEROP:

  • This post from the Chrome team outlines the specific 26 focus areas for Interop this year.
  • ..and here's a post from the WebKit team outlining their 2023Â commitment.
  • You can see a live dashboard of 2023's Interop efforts.
  • This post gives an overview of the outcomes of the Interop 2022 project.

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Microsoft is adding new AI-powered search features to Bing and Edge.

  • This Tweet thread looks at why making a dark mode is so tricky to get right, and shares someÂ tips.

  • Here's an in-depth, web-based course for working with images on theÂ web.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

How To Build a 'Magazine Layout' with CSS Grid Areas â€” A practical look at how to use the capabilities of CSS Grid to â€œachieve layouts that look like they were laid out byÂ handâ€.

Jennifer Brehm

ElementInternals and Form-Associated Custom Elements â€” As of Safari Technology Preview 162 support for the ElementInternals API is enabled, bringing it up to speed with otherÂ browsers.

Ryosuke Niwa

â–¶Â Â Self-Hosting Fonts (@font-face) Explained (including GoogleÂ Fonts) â€” A 15-minute video from Kevin in his usual accessible style on hosting fonts, making them performant, and why you may need to do it yourself anyway when it comes to GDPRÂ compliance.

Kevin Powell

â–¶Â Â "React Isn't Great at Anything Except Being Popular" with JoshÂ Collinsworth

Whiskey Web and Whatnot sponsorpodcast

A color-contrast() Strategy for Complementary TranslucentÂ Backgrounds â€” Adam demos a potential â€˜future CSS trickâ€™ for dynamically contrasting text with a supportive translucent background to ensure maximum accessibility. Read the comments for further context, as this is just a bit of wish casting at thisÂ point.

Adam Argyle

Bringing Letters to Life: Coding a Kinetic SVG Typography Animation â€” Learn how to recreate a neat motion type effect using SVG andÂ GreenSock. There's code examples and CodePen demos to help things along.

Louis Hoebregts

'My Favourite 3 Lines of CSS' â€” ...revealing just how powerful CSS custom propertiesÂ are.

Andy Bell

How to Favicon in 2023: Six Files That Fit Most Needs
Andrey Sitnik

Building a Stylish Masonry Layout using CSS and JavaScript
Andrico Karoulla

Testing Color Accessibility with Dev Tools
Michelle Barker

Quirks of the Page Visibility API
Matt Joseph

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Vanilla List: A Directory of Vanilla JavaScript Plugins â€” But note that the plugins themselves may have multiple dependencies, just not stuff like jQuery, React, etc.

Glitch.Family

â–¶Â Â ScrollyVideo.js: Responsive 'Scrollable' Videos â€” Itâ€™s an interesting effect and well demonstrated here. Compatible with React, Svelte, Vue, or just plain oleâ€™ HTML.

Daniel Kao

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut â€” The best issue tracking software is one that software developers are actually happy toÂ use.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

lawnmower: A Library to Build VR Layouts Using HTML Tags â€” A web component library that aims â€œto make building a basic VR website as easy to make as your first HTML siteâ€. Thereâ€™s a 10-minute video showing it offÂ here. Getting flashbacks to the X3D and VRML erasÂ :-)

Gareth Marland

Swiper 9.0: Mobile Touch Slider with Accelerated Transitions â€” Tree shakable, library agnostic, and focused entirely on modern browsers and web APIs. RTL support too. GitHubÂ repo.

Vladimir Kharlampidi

URL Animations: Add Loading Animations to a Site's URL â€” Certainly a novelty that you wonâ€™t use on many projects, if any! You can check out lots of different live examples here.

Abubukker Chaudhary

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Software Engineer â€” Join our happy team. Stimulus is a social platform started by Sticker Mule to show what's possible if your mission is to increase humanÂ happiness.
Stimulus

Senior Frontend Software Engineer â€” Help us redefine how work is done. Join our remote engineering team and work on hard problems. React, TS, GQL, Storybook, AI/LLMÂ ğŸš€
Qatalog

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

Ipx.

items.title: Mixing color directly in CSS
items.content:
TOGETHER WITH â–¶Â WhiskeyÂ Web andÂ Whatnot

#â€‹578 â€” February 1, 2023 | Read on the web

CSS color-mix() â€” Browser support is lacking right now, but the CSS color-mix() function is set to ship in Chrome 111. It can be used to take any colors, in any of the supported color spaces, and mix them directly from your stylesheet. This post explainsÂ how.

Adam Argyle (Chrome Developers)

ğŸ¨ RELATED â€” Sticking with the topic of handling color in CSS:

  • Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡ looks at CSS color functions and custom properties, highlighting the appeal of functions like hsl(), hwb(), andÂ lab().
  • Austin Gil brings together a handy list for working with CSS Name Colors. It contains Named Color groups, palettes, favorites, and even funÂ facts.

â–¶Â Â React Isnâ€™t Great at Anything Except Being Popular â€” You may have seen the controversial blog post by Josh Collinsworth about React not being the best choice anymore. In this episode, we dive into why React hasnâ€™t aged well and what the best frameworks areÂ today.

Whiskey Web and Whatnot sponsorpodcast

Easy SVG Customization and Animation: A Practical Guide â€” Adrian Bece notes that devs may often feel discouraged from editing SVG markup and experimenting with animations, thinking itâ€™s a significant time investment or there is a need to use a complex animation libraries. Here, he showcases some of his favorite SVG tricks, making the process streamlined and fun. Plenty of neat examples hereÂ too to help things along.

Smashing Magazine

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • After 28 years the W3C, undoubtedly one of the most important organizational bodies working on the web, has re-launched as a public-interest non-profit. There's some additional context here if you want to know more about the change.

  • Netlify announced today that they have acquired Gatsby.

  • Thinking about the size of your site and how it may load on mobile? This chart shows the average cost of 1GB of mobile data in selected countries.

  • Discord user? The MDN Web Docs has a community server.

  • â–¶ï¸ A quick video showing you what View Transitions for the webÂ enable.

  • Adriana and Diego, from Google and Microsoft respectively, â–¶ï¸ share three tips to improve your web app's experience.

  • Did you know the World Wide Web once had its own logo?

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Building an Accessible Theme Picker â€” This is an attractively presented and easy to follow tutorial for a handy siteÂ feature, complete with keyboard navigation and screen reader support.

Sarah L. Fossheim

Three Attributes for Better Web Forms â€” Theyâ€™re inputmode, enterkeyhint, and autocomplete.

Jeremy Keith

scrollend: A New JavaScript Event â€” Finally an event you wonâ€™t need a hotel booking for. scrollend provides a new way to detect that a scrolling operation is complete in the browser. Is it another Chrome-only nicety? Surprisingly not â€“ Firefox 109+ supports itÂ too.

Adam Argyle (Chrome Team)

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. UseÂ Shortcut â€” The best issue tracking software is one that software developers are actually happy toÂ use.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Accessible Hamburger Buttons Without JavaScript â€” Sometimes you need to consider if modern techniques allow you to avoid JavaScript. Hereâ€™s a CodePen if you want toÂ play.

Pausly

Creating a High-Contrast Design System with CSS CustomÂ Properties â€” Managing our colors can truly help people to access our content â€” as such, this article takes a deep dive into how we can create a high-contrast system while maintaining a balance between designing something accessible and respecting the look and feel of aÂ brand.

Brecht De Ruyte

Greater Styling Control Over Type with initial-letter â€” An overview of the new CSS property initial-letter for more styling control over the firstÂ letter.

Stephanie Stimac

Your Web Performance is Too Reactive; Itâ€™s Time to Do More Than Put Out Fires - Calibre â€” Notes that a â€˜wait-and-see speed strategyâ€™ isnâ€™t the best for your site, before offering up some pointers on being proactive with web performance, how best to test, and how to get buy-in from yourÂ team.

Karolina Szczur

Why We Switched CDNs: How Google's Core Web Vitals Led Us to Cloudflare Pages â€” In order to deal with issues with time to first byte (TTFB) in their Core Web Vitals assessment, this post compares TTFB results from Netlify, Vercel, Cloudflare Pages and GatsbyÂ Cloud.

Michael Orenstein

A Better Way to Work With Number and Date Inputs in JavaScript
Steve Sewell

Screen Readers' Support for Text Level HTML Semantics
Steve Faulkner

How to Lazy Load Disqus for Improved Site Performance
Alex MacArthur

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Sailboat UI: A Modern UI Component Library for Tailwind CSS â€” Includes a common set of 150+ ready-to-use components and is easy to theme to your liking based on configurationÂ settings.

Sailboat UI

Shoelace 2.0: 'A Forward-Thinking Library of Web Components' â€” A collection of well designed every day UI components (buttons, drawers, inputs, menus, color pickers, and more) built in a framework agnosticÂ way.

Cory LaViska

Need an Extra Pair of Hands on Your React Project? ContactÂ UsÂ ğŸš€

UpgradeJS by OmbuLabs sponsor

GradienMood: Generate a Gradient from a Mood â€” This is different! Type a word or prompt representing a â€œmoodâ€ and this AI-based tool will show you a copy/pasteable CSS gradient that matches what you typed (try 'calm looking gradient that is purplish color' for example). Thereâ€™s also a gallery of â€œmoodsâ€ toÂ browse.

GradienMood

Theme Toggles: A Small Set of Unique, Animated Dark ModeÂ Toggles â€” Theyâ€™re all built with SVG, accessible, and can be included as inline SVG or React, and of course you can try out each one directly on theÂ page.

Theme Toggles

clamp() Calculator: A Handy Tool for Getting Viewport-Based ClampedÂ Values
Chris Burnell

CodeImage: A Tool to Manage and Beautify Your Code Screenshots
Riccardo Perra

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

Ipx.

items.title: The importance of optimizing for that first byte
items.content:
#â€‹577 â€” January 25, 2023 | Read on the web

Level Up Your CSS Skills with the :has()Â Selector â€” Weâ€™ve spoken a fair bit about the CSS relational selector :has() in recent months, noting how it offers up techniques and methods that was previously impossible without JavaScript. With browser support now growing, Stephanie Eckles takes a detailed look at some of its â€˜magicalÂ powersâ€™.

Smashing Magazine

If you're wondering what :has() could do for you, Liam Johnston shares some ideas in More Real-World Uses for :has()

Astro 2.0 â€” Version 2.0 of this popular web framework is out now and includes hybrid rendering (allowing mixing of SSR and SSG outputs), type safety on Markdown, an upgrade to Vite 4.0 internally andÂ more.

Astro

Creating an Interactive Whiteboard with Amazon IVS Chat â€” Live streaming is mostly known for entertainment related streams like gaming or sports, but it is a perfect tool for delivering educational content. Learn about an interesting use case for Amazon IVS chat rooms - live, interactiveÂ whiteboards.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

Optimizing the Time to First Byte â€” A sound look at how to optimize for the 'Time to First Byte' metric â€” a foundational performance metric that precedes every other meaningfulÂ metric.

Jeremy Wagner

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Dave Rupert shares his wishlist for CSS in 2023.

  • Wikipedia has a new look, this post looks at some of theÂ changes.

  • This post looks at just how Apple Silicon (i.e. M1, M2) is "breaking developer workflows", and why it could be a catalyst for server-side WebAssembly.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

OK, OKLCH ğŸ‘‘ â€” Is OKLCH worthy of being crowned the winner of technological choices when it comes to CSS color options? Chris shares the rather rosyÂ picture so far.

Chris Coyier

WebKit Features in Safari 16.3 â€” An overview of what new features are landing in Safari 16.3, including several CSS and Web APIÂ fixes.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut. â€” The best issue tracking software is one that software developers are actually happy toÂ use.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Getting Started with SvelteKit â€” SvelteKit only recently hit 1.0 and this is a comprehensive overview of how to build a site using it. It covers topics like routing, layouts, data, props andÂ more.

Adam Rackis

Two Ways to Safely Break a Long Word in HTML â€” If you have a long word that doesnâ€™t fit into a container, it will overflow and break your layout. To avoid this, Amit shares two ways to safely fixÂ it.

Amit Merchant

International Domain Names: Where Does meÃŸagefactory.ca Lead You? â€” The result depends on yourÂ browser.

Daniel Lemire

Deploying CSS Logical Properties on Web Apps â€” How CSS Logical properties are â€œa perfect fitâ€ for right-to-leftÂ interfaces.

Nicolas Hoffmann

Things I Want to See in Frontend Development in 2023
Paul Armstrong

Status of the New SVG Engine in WebKit
Nikolas Zimmermann

How to Transition to Manifest V3 for Chrome Extensions
Shane Duggan

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

PSone.css â€” Look, I was on team N64 back in the 90s, but I can still appreciate this very cool PlayStation 1 style CSS framework â€” strong Final Fantasy VIIÂ vibes.

micah5 and Igor Guastalla

CSS Generators: A Set of Code Generators for CSSÂ Effects â€” Includes helpful and easy-to-use tools for text & box shadows, glow effects, and unique textÂ underlines.

CSS Bud

Shifty: A Small, Fast Tweening Engine â€” All it does is tweening. Itâ€™s a low level animation solution that you can integrate into any rendering mechanism of your choice. The examples here demonstrate it well as it can be used for â€˜animatingâ€™ things in an unconventional sense. GitHubÂ repo.

Jeremy Kahn

Tuple, a Lightning-Fast Pairing Tool Built for RemoteÂ Developers

Tuple sponsor

Barba.js: For Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages â€” You certainly canâ€™t say the projectâ€™s homepage doesnâ€™t show off all of its features! For such a dramatic set of effects, things feel smooth and.. surprisingly tolerable ğŸ˜ GitHubÂ repo.

De Rosa, Michel, et al.

tailwindcss-fluid-type: A Plugin to Easily Integrate Fluid Typography in Tailwind Projects â€” Fluid typography ensures typography is consistent with viewport size and available space. You can see a live example of the plugin here.

David Hellmann

DummyJSON: A REST API for Accessing Fake JSON Data for Placeholder Content â€” The available data is in all sorts of categories like products, shopping carts, users, posts, comments, andÂ more.

Muhammad Ovi

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ˜ Pixel Vibes

Improved Web Component for Pixel-Accurate Atkinson Dithered Images â€” You may remember at the end of last year we shared a web component that displays images using the Atkinson dithering algorithm â€” well, Andrew is back with an improved versionÂ two. Repo here.

Andrew Stephens

items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹577 â€” January 25, 2023 | Read on the web

          
        



  





  
  
Level Up Your CSS Skills with the :has()Â Selector â€” Weâ€™ve spoken a fair bit about the CSS relational selector :has() in recent months, noting how it offers up techniques and methods that was previously impossible without JavaScript. With browser support now growing, Stephanie Eckles takes a detailed look at some of its â€˜magicalÂ powersâ€™.
Smashing Magazine 


If you're wondering what :has() could do for you, Liam Johnston shares some ideas in More Real-World Uses for :has()





  
  
Astro 2.0 â€” Version 2.0 of this popular web framework is out now and includes hybrid rendering (allowing mixing of SSR and SSG outputs), type safety on Markdown, an upgrade to Vite 4.0 internally andÂ more.
Astro 


  
  
Creating an Interactive Whiteboard with Amazon IVS Chat â€” Live streaming is mostly known for entertainment related streams like gaming or sports, but it is a perfect tool for delivering educational content. Learn about an interesting use case for Amazon IVS chat rooms - live, interactiveÂ whiteboards.
Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor


  
  
Optimizing the Time to First Byte â€” A sound look at how to optimize for the 'Time to First Byte' metric â€” a foundational performance metric that precedes every other meaningfulÂ metric.
Jeremy Wagner 




âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF
Dave Rupert shares his wishlist for CSS in 2023.
Wikipedia has a new look, this post looks at some of theÂ changes.
This post looks at just how Apple Silicon (i.e. M1, M2) is "breaking developer workflows", and why it could be a catalyst for server-side WebAssembly.






ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion




  





  
  
OK, OKLCH ğŸ‘‘ â€” Is OKLCH worthy of being crowned the winner of technological choices when it comes to CSS color options? Chris shares the rather rosyÂ picture so far.
Chris Coyier 


  
  
WebKit Features in Safari 16.3 â€” An overview of what new features are landing in Safari 16.3, including several CSS and Web APIÂ fixes.
Jen Simmons (WebKit) 


  
  
Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut. â€” The best issue tracking software is one that software developers are actually happy toÂ use.
Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor


  
  
Getting Started with SvelteKit â€” SvelteKit only recently hit 1.0 and this is a comprehensive overview of how to build a site using it. It covers topics like routing, layouts, data, props andÂ more.
Adam Rackis 


  
  
Two Ways to Safely Break a Long Word in HTML â€” If you have a long word that doesnâ€™t fit into a container, it will overflow and break your layout. To avoid this, Amit shares two ways to safely fixÂ it.
Amit Merchant 


  
  
International Domain Names: Where Does meÃŸagefactory.ca Lead You? â€” The result depends on yourÂ browser.
Daniel Lemire 


  
  
Deploying CSS Logical Properties on Web Apps â€” How CSS Logical properties are â€œa perfect fitâ€ for right-to-leftÂ interfaces.
Nicolas Hoffmann 


  
Things I Want to See in Frontend Development in 2023
  
Paul Armstrong 
  


  
Status of the New SVG Engine in WebKit
  
Nikolas Zimmermann 
  


  
How to Transition to Manifest V3 for Chrome Extensions
  
Shane Duggan

PSone.css â€” Look, I was on team N64 back in the 90s, but I can still appreciate this very cool PlayStation 1 style CSS framework â€” strong Final Fantasy VIIÂ vibes.
micah5 and Igor Guastalla 


  
  
CSS Generators: A Set of Code Generators for CSSÂ Effects â€” Includes helpful and easy-to-use tools for text & box shadows, glow effects, and unique textÂ underlines.
CSS Bud 


  
  
Shifty: A Small, Fast Tweening Engine â€” All it does is tweening. Itâ€™s a low level animation solution that you can integrate into any rendering mechanism of your choice. The examples here demonstrate it well as it can be used for â€˜animatingâ€™ things in an unconventional sense. GitHubÂ repo.
Jeremy Kahn 


  
  
Tuple, a Lightning-Fast Pairing Tool Built for RemoteÂ Developers
Tuple sponsor


  
  
Barba.js: For Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages â€” You certainly canâ€™t say the projectâ€™s homepage doesnâ€™t show off all of its features! For such a dramatic set of effects, things feel smooth and.. surprisingly tolerable ğŸ˜ GitHubÂ repo.

items.title: The truth about CSS Selector performance
items.content:
#â€‹576 â€” January 18, 2023 | Read on the web

The Truth About CSS Selector Performance â€” Did you know that certain CSS selectors are faster than others? This article explains, outlining the ones that are important to keep an eye on for performance, and shares how a new tool in Microsoft Edge can help you measure theÂ impact.

Patrick Brosset

Top Front-End Tools of 2022 â€” Louis takes a look at the most useful frontend tools for CSS and JavaScript developers that were most popular last year (and will hopefully help speed up your developmentÂ workflows).

Louis Lazaris

Dynaboard: The Pro-Code Web App IDE Made for Developers â€” Build high performance public and private web apps in a collaborative â€” code forward â€” WYSIWYGÂ environment.

Dynaboard sponsor

Optimizing the Image Element LCP â€” Largest Contentful Paint (or LCP) is both a major web performance metric, and ranking factor. Here, EloÃ¯se provides an overview of the best practices for the integration and optimization of an LCPÂ image.

EloÃ¯se Martin

Why Not document.write()? â€” Weâ€™re often told not to use document.write(), butâ€¦ why?! Harry digs in, noting that it â€œguarantees both a blocking fetch and a blocking execution, which holds up the parser for far longer thanÂ necessaryâ€.

Harry Roberts

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Dave Rupert will be joining Kevin Powell for â–¶ï¸ a YouTube livestream later today diving into Web Components.

  • The CSS property initial-letter will be landing in Chrome 110 - more on this in Stephanie's blog post.

  • All of the modules in Carie Fisher's excellent 'Learn Accessbility' course are now avaialble.

  • Last week we shared the most hearted CodePen demos of 2022, now Steve Gardner has collected his own 'Hall of Fame' favorites/bests.

  • ğŸ“… TheJam.dev is an upcoming, free two-day virtual conference taking place next week â€”Â it focuses on how to build modern web apps using Jamstack, serverless and more.

  • ğŸ“… Early-bird tickets for CSS Day taking place in Amsterdam, Netherlands, this June are now available.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Discovering the Capable Web â€” What advanced web capabilities does your browser support? Just how Fugu is your browser? Thomas explains Project Fugu and a set of new APIs â€”Â â€a cross company effort to close gaps in the webâ€™s capabilities, enabling new classes of applications to run on theÂ webâ€.

Thomas Steiner (Chrome Developers)

Priority Hints and Optimizing LCP â€” Priority Hints are used to indicate to the browser the relative priority of a resource. Here, web performance expert Kevin takes a deep dive into how you can go about improving your Largest Contentful Paint by using fetchpriority.

Kevin Farrugia

Free Website Speed Test: Does Your Site Meet Google's Core Web Vitals? â€” Get an in-depth technical analysis of your site and learn how to make it fast. Rank higher in Google & deliver greatÂ UX.

DebugBear sponsor

Using :is() in Complex Selectors Selects More Than You Might Initially Think â€” Because selector matching happens from right to left, you might end up with more matches than youÂ expected.

Bramus Van Damme

A History of Web Browser Engines from 1990 to Today â€” An interesting overview and timeline of browser engine marketshare over the past ~33 years. This was last updated in October of last year, but we havenâ€™t shared it here in the newsletterÂ before.

Alphonse Eylenburg

â–¶Â Â Working with WebXR and Three.js â€” A short series of YouTube videos on the basics of creating VR and augmented reality experiences using WebÂ APIs.

Mohit Kumar Toshniwal

Not Everyone's Currently Building for The Web, But Probably More PeopleÂ Should
Thomas Steiner

Building a Color Palette with CSS: Three Methods
Rahul Chhodde

Six Common SVG Fails (And How to Fix Them)
Mariana Beldi

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

SSSVG: An Interactive SVG Reference â€” A handy visual and interactive SVG reference. Quickly look up how to define SVG shapes, transforms, masks, patterns, gradients, text andÂ more.

SÃ©bastien NoÃ«l

Lazy Brush 2.0: A Library for Smooth Pointer Drawing â€” Allow your users to draw smooth curves and straight lines with your mouse, finger or any pointing device. This long standing library has just migrated to TypeScript and gained a new â€˜frictionâ€™ option to customize the feel. GitHubÂ repo.

Jan Hug

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. UseÂ Shortcut

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

contrast-ratio: A Tool to Calculate the Contrast Ratio Between any Two Valid CSS Colors

Lea Verou

Ripple UI: A Collection of Tailwind Components and Utilities â€” A nice collection of 20+ customizable components with support for dark mode out-of-the-box. Includes good documentation and examples for eachÂ component.

Mauricio Siu

Accessible Color Palette Generator: Beautiful WCAG-Compliant Colors â€” Includes a gallery where each pair of colors follow WCAG 2.1 AA based on a contrast ratio of 4.5:1, or you can generate a pair from a single color of yourÂ own.

Venngage

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Software Engineer â€” Stimulus is a social platform started by Sticker Mule to show what's possible if your mission is to increase human happiness. Join our engineeringÂ team.
Stimulus

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

Ipx.

title: Frontend Focus
description: A onceâ€“weekly roundup of the best front-end news, articles and tutorials. HTML, CSS, WebGL, Canvas, browser tech, and more.
